title: How to Take Party Photographs

steps.headline: Develop a plan for your photo album as you are planning the event.
steps.description: Plan the album cover: If the party is to honor a friend or colleague for their birthday you might want to have a close up picture of the honoree (perhaps holding a sign or wearing a ribbon or hat announcing their birthday) as well as a group picture of everyone attending the party surrounding the honoree. Organize your photo album as a book with many chapters. You might, for example, have chapters for food preparation, the food buffet, the guest of honor arriving, opening gifts, the cake, telling stories, a chapter for each game, and a chapter for the cleanup crew. For the first page of each chapter you might want to get a photograph of the people involved in that activity holding a sign announcing the activity. For the food preparation chapter you might want to have a full page for each person who made a special dish holding their specialty dish with, possibly the recipe for that dish in a text box on the page.

steps.headline: Have your cameras out long before guests arrive at the party.
steps.description: Take photos of your setup. Check photos to be sure that the lighting is good. Take photographs of groups of people as they arrive.

steps.headline: Be sure to get some group shots.
steps.description: If your party is an 'event', then there will be a core group of people that you want to get. If it is 'just a party', then try getting shots of the various groups that are there.

steps.headline: Capture the feeling.
steps.description: Try to avoid lots of photos in which the participants are posing like tin soldiers. Is it a 'staid' event? Maybe a Christmas Party? Halloween?? ?

steps.headline: Take pictures when people are unaware.
steps.description: Another good reason to break out the camera early is because people will be a lot more amenable to surprise shots if they know there is a camera floating around.

steps.headline: Don't be afraid to use your zoom.
steps.description: Either zooming in or out can make for an interesting shot. Try to capture facial expressions in your photographs.

steps.headline: Watch out for the much feared 'red eye'!!
steps.description: Quite often, this is a result of using your on camera flash.

steps.headline: Try to avoid using your on camera flash.
steps.description: Go for natural lighting whenever possible.

steps.headline: If this is an 'event', know the schedule.
steps.description: Know when the keynote speaker is supposed to speak, when the break out sessions are, etc.

steps.headline: Try different perspectives.
steps.description: This can be something like shooting from your chair or at an unusual angle.

steps.headline: Consider having multiple digital cameras sitting around.
steps.description: Those can result in a variety of shots that you would never have gotten otherwise.

steps.headline: Hand off your camera to someone else.
steps.description: Everyone gets stuck in a rut and their pictures can show that. Have someone else taking photographs for you.

steps.headline: After the party:
steps.description: Edit your photos: add fill lighting, crop to remove extraneous background Label all photos: name of people, what they were doing. Organize your photos into a nice album, adding captions as appropriate. Distribute the album to the honoree and guests.
